awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Pediatric Breath Practice Spirometry Device
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a product designed to enable healthcare technicians to practice spirometry testing with children. Respiratory therapists and pulmonologists working with pediatric patients will gain an increased understanding of patient progress and improve the accuracy of their diagnoses. This medical device may also be used for geriatric populations as a complete spirometry test is often required as part of both preoperative and postoperative medical protocols in in-patient and out-patient medical facilities. 

This I-Corps project is seeks to develop practical and convenient tools for respiratory therapists and pulmonologists. Assessment of lung disorders and other respiratory ailments often includes Pulmonary Function Testing (PFT) and the most common type of PFT is spirometry. In order to complete spirometry testing, the patient must be able to exhale for six seconds with no backflow of air. Many children are unable to complete the test properly, so they are sent home with a mouthpiece and nose-clip to practice. This practice method is ineffective because there is no way to monitor the patient’s progress. The proposed innovation allows parents to monitor the child’s learning progress and ensure that the children are practicing correctly. The new technology is a hand-held airflow monitoring device designed specifically for pediatric use. The device consists of a small cylindrical tube with a mouthpiece and internal electronic components that deliver audio and visual cues to the user.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The outcome of the I-Corps project “Pediatric Breath Practice Spirometry Device” is as follows: 

PEDbreathe, a pediatric spirometry practice device, aims to reduce failed spirometry tests in clinics for patients aged 5-17, potentially saving clinicians an average of $492 per day. The team explored business and marketing strategies for PEDbreathe. It was initially considered selling to hospitals. After the interviews supported by the I-Corps program, the team pivoted towards direct marketing to end-users. This was due to identified challenges in obtaining a “CPT code”, which is used for insurance claims. 

Key insights were gained through interviews with pulmonologists, parents, and patients, revealing the device's potential and guiding future steps like producing devices for IRB studies and exploring mass production. The project supported by the I-Corps program emphasized continuous customer discovery and business model validation. The key takeaways were: 1. There is a need for the PEDBreathe device from pulmonologists and patients. 2. Additional demographic markets discovered (Geriatrics, families with language barriers, intellectual/developmental disabilities). 3. KOLs and the referral revenue model may be the best commercialization path. 3. More customer discovery and research is needed. 

The outcomes and findings of the PEDbreathe I-Corps project address the National Science Foundation’s criteria of intellectual merit and broader impacts in the following ways:

Intellectual Merit: PEDbreathe's innovative approach to pediatric spirometry practice addresses a significant gap in current clinical practices. By aiming to reduce failed spirometry tests in clinics, the device demonstrates potential for advancing knowledge in the field of pediatric respiratory care.

Broader Impacts: The device has a direct impact on the broader community by potentially saving clinicians significant costs per day. The project's emphasis on customer discovery and business model validation showcases its potential societal benefit, especially for pediatric patients and healthcare providers. Engaging with pulmonologists, parents, and patients also highlights the project's commitment to addressing real-world problems and improving health outcomes for children.

A Business Model Canvas (BMC) was created, outlining the goals and objectives of a potential business that the team worked with.

Future plans for the project will be to further test the developed prototypes with patients, obtain direct feedback, and apply for the NSF or NIH STTR/SBIR program.  

 


Last Modified: 12/10/2023
Modified by: Morten O Jensen
